description.narrative: (i) Diversifying the power generation mix in the DR: Currently the DR relies primarily on imported, expensive fuel to generate power. The Project would enable local wind resources, rather than imported fuel, to generate power; furthermore, the cost of the Project''s power is significantly less than current wholesale power prices in the DR, so the country will add lower cost power to the energy mix; (ii) The Project is expected to generate approx. 156 GWh per annum of clean, non-fossil fuel dependent electricity generation that will displace an estimated 110,000 tCO2e per annum, leading to improved air quality and climate change mitigation.

Parques Eólicos del Caribe S.A (PECASA or the Company) is currently developing a 50 MW greenfield wind power plant. The plant will consist of: i) installation of 25x 2 MW Gamesa G97 wind turbine generators, ii) construction of a 14 km 138 kV transmission line; and iii) construction of access roads, a substation, and foundations/ platforms for the WTGs (the Project). The Project is located near the town of Villa Vasquez in the province of Montecristi, in the northwestern part of the Dominican Republic (DR). The Project is being developed pursuant to a 20 year concession awarded by the Comisión Nacional de la Energía (CNE) of the DR The Project is expected to produce approximately 156 Gwhs annually and will sell 100% of power produced to Corporacion Dominicana de Empresas Electricas Estatales (CDEEE) under a 20 year power purchase agreement (PPA). The Project construction is expected to commence in November 2012 and be completed and commissioned by year end 2013.

name.narrative: The Project is being developed near the town of Villa Vasquez in the province of Monecristi, in the northwestern part of the Dominican Republic (DR). The Project site is located in an area of agricultural farmland used primarily for farming and livestock grazing activities. The closest communities are over two kilometers away from the Project site, and the wind farm operation poses little to no risk to their safety. Land use at the site will be unmodified, and property owners will be able to continue with their agricultural and cattle grazing activities. The wind farm, access roads, and connecting underground cables will affect a total of 120 private properties. The Company has provided evidence that it has entered into 20 year use agreements with the owners and/or current users.
